newsitem.title: UK: Britain's Offer says electricity prices fell in 96.
newsitem.headline: Britain's Offer says electricity prices fell in 96.

text.p: Britain's electricity industry regulator Offer said on Wednesday that domestic customers had seen prices fall by five percent in 1996 while prices for industrial customers decreased by between four and five percent, reflecting revisions to price reviews from April 1996.
"All customers continue to benefit from reductions in prices," Offer head Stephen Littlechild said in a statement marking publication of the watchdog's annual report.
Offer said disconnections had fallen 43 percent to 477 across the country, with all companies but Northern Electric in north east England showing a reduction.
Offer said 57 percent of users above one megaWatt (MW) were choosing second-tier supply with 38 percent of users between 100 kiloWatt and one MW choosing supply.
Offer said around 4,000 MW of new generating capacity came onstream during the year with a further 2,375 MW under construction.
There was also "good progress" towards targets for energy efficiency with projects underway which are expected to make savings in usage equivalent to over 80 percent of current four-year targets.
